title: 113_hr1931
content: The Act may be cited as the "Employees of America Streamlining for Your Savings Act of 2013" or the "EASY Savings Act of 2013." It enhances the authority to make cash awards to employees for cost-saving disclosures. The Employees of America Streamlining for Your Savings Act of 2013, also known as the EASY Savings Act of 2013, amends Section 4512 of title 5, United States Code to enhance the authority for cash awards to employees for identifying surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority. The Inspector General or designated agency employee must refer any identified surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority to the Chief Financial Officer of the agency. The EASY Savings Act of 2013 allows employees to identify surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority, which can be transferred to the Treasury for deficit reduction if deemed appropriate by the agency's Chief Financial Officer. Transfers are not subject to Title X of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The EASY Savings Act of 2013 allows agencies to transfer surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority to the Treasury for deficit reduction. The head of an agency can retain up to 10% of these amounts for cash awards to employees who identify such funds. Annual reports on disclosures of fraud, waste, or mismanagement must be submitted to the Office of Personnel Management. The EASY Savings Act of 2013 allows agencies to transfer surplus funds to the Treasury for deficit reduction. Employees who identify such funds can receive cash awards. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management must submit an annual report to Congress on Federal cost savings and awards. Each agency's cash award program must comply with the Act, and the head of each agency must include relevant information. The EASY Savings Act of 2013 requires agencies to include cost savings and awards program information in budget requests. The Comptroller General must report to Congress every 3 years on the program's operation and suggest legislative changes. Additionally, a prohibition on cash awards to certain officers is outlined in Section 4509 of title 5, United States Code. Section 4509 of title 5, United States Code prohibits certain officers from receiving cash awards under this subchapter if they are the head of an agency, serve in specific high-level positions, or are voting members of an independent establishment. Prohibition of cash awards for certain officers under title 5, United States Code.
